thread.title: Consumer confidence dives in September
thread.title_full: Consumer confidence dives in September | Business Spectator

author: Michael Roddan
title: Consumer confidence dives in September
text:
Consumer confidence has plunged over the last month, as concerns around stockmarket volatility and the sliding Australian dollar play on consumers' minds, with economic pessimists far outweighing optimists.
The Westpac-Melbourne Institute Consumer Sentiment Index fell by 5.6 per cent to 93.9 in September, down from a read of 99.5 in August.
“This print on the Index now marks the 17th out of the last 19 months that the Index has been below 100," Westpac chief economist Bill Evans said.
A level below 100 indicates that pessimists outnumber optimists.
Mr Evans said the plunge in confidence was a result of the "deluge of disturbing news" around volatility in Australian and overseas stockmarkets, poor economic data from China and a disappointing print on local GDP figures, which last week showed a quarterly increase of just 0.2 per cent.
"This solid fall in the Index comes as no surprise," Mr Evans said.
"The underlying picture is that confidence has been little changed over the last year - firmly stuck below 100 and averaging around 96."
September's survey also included a question asking respondents to provide a news item they could recall. Mr Evans said the most recalled items were around domestic economics conditions and overseas issues.
“News on the Australian dollar was noted by 15.5 per cent of respondents -- the highest on the dollar since June 2002," Mr Evans said.
The weakness in the Australian dollar was likely to have unnerved households, he said. The currency has plunged to a fresh six-year low, diving below US70c for the first time since 2009.
“The government would be pleased to see that ‘budget and taxation’ caught the attention of only 23.1 per cent of respondents compared to 62.7 per cent in September last year," Mr Evans said.
